data.title: Busy P
data.meta_description: Explore the Red Bull Music Academy archive, tracing the global music institutionâs more than 20-year history
data.text:
Gerd Janson

We have a nice gentleman from Paris, France here, who goes by the name of Pedro Winter, aka Busy P. He has done a few things behind the scenes, as well as on the scenes. He has been the manager of a well-known duo and another well-known duo, and of a great and quite successful label called Ed Banger. So, please give this man a very warm welcome. [applause]

Pedro Winter

Bonjour, bonjour. So, yes, I am from Paris, France, I crossed the channel to come to London. In fact, I am in town to celebrate the seven years of my small label, Ed Banger Records. We are throwing a party tonight and Red Bull people gently proposed me to come and visit you, and I like this kind of unprepared stuff. You are from all over the world, I believe. Anyone here from France except me and those two crazy drunk guys I met yesterday? We are the only Frenchies. So this is amazing, Iâve been lucky enough to visit the Academy this morning.

Gerd Janson

We are glad to have you here. But who is Ed Banger?

Pedro Winter

I was jealous, in fact. If I can speak to the Red Bull people, I was jealous that Iâd never been invited to such a crazy thing, having your own studio 24 hours a day. I wish I could come and, like... How has it been so far? Any good tracks? Did you achieve something or did you just get drunk in London and get far away from your country? Both? Good.

Gerd Janson

Itâs like Christmas for them, extended over two weeks.

Pedro Winter

Me, the only Academy I trust is the Police Academy, but Iâm happy to see what is going on at the Red Bull Music Academy.

Gerd Janson

So you didnât go to music school?

Pedro Winter

No, I wanted to become a lawyer. When youâre a kid you want to be an astronaut, you want to be a fireman, you want to be an actor, you want to be a star. Me, I wanted to be a lawyer.

Gerd Janson

Why a lawyer?

Pedro Winter

I donât know, itâs not sexy, but this is how it was in my head at the time. I knew I wanted to be a lawyer in the entertainment business. Sorry, Iâm going back to get to slowly arrive to what Iâm doing right now. I wanted to be part of the entertainment business, but I wanted to be behind. I wanted to create the magic, all the work you have to do put on a show. The work you have to do to put out a record. So I started my university. I have to be honest, I did it for three months.

Gerd Janson

You were that quick a learner? It only took you three months to get your degree?

Pedro Winter

It took me three months to be lucky enough to meet some guys in a record shop in Paris, and it was the Daft Punk boys. I was only 20 years old, I was a bit late at school. At the time in Paris, I was throwing some parties in a club and I invited them to play for me.

Gerd Janson

What kind of parties?

Pedro Winter

At the time it was in â95 and my life was all about house music, especially New York house music. So, Kenny Dope and Louie Vega were my gods, I have the biggest collection of Masters At Work recordings. For those of you who know them, you know itâs hard âcause those guys areâ¦

Gerd Janson

Very prolific, it was like a remix a week.

Pedro Winter

Every two days, man. Especially in â95. So, it was really house music, and you probably know those names, but at the time the guys playing in my parties were DJ Gregory, Dimitri From Paris, Philippe Zdar of Motorbass, who became Cassius later on. And then two robots, the Daft Punk boys. So we became friends. We were 20 years old, the three of us. We are from 1975. And I quit school, I quit university. There was no point continuing in trying to become a lawyer and at the same time throwing parties, traveling the world and trying to learn a job. And I learned the management business, even though I hate this. I donât feel comfortable being a manager.

Gerd Janson

Before we come to the managing part of managing a group, what attracted you that kind of house music from New York, especially? If you want to be pigeonholing, itâs a very different musical style from what people associate with you these days.

Pedro Winter

If you want to go back, back, back, my very first rave party in â92 in Paris, I discovered electronic music with a pop group called Deee- Lite that you probably all know. But I didnât fall in love with Deee-Lite for âGroove Is In The Heart,â but I fell in love with the track âWhat Is Love,â which I hope you all know, a track from the album in 1989. This is the first time I got repetitive music in my face. You know, when youâre 14 years old you can start to realize things. Before that you get it from people around you, your brother, your cousins, your parents, radio. But itâs not your choice, you know? I love it when people say, âI discovered Run DMC when I was 10 years old.â Thatâs not true, at 10 years old you shut up and youâre just listening to what people are throwing at you. So âWhat Is Loveâ in â89, I thought I love this kind of trance, repetitive music. Then electronic music arrived in France in the gay clubs, but at the time I was too small, too young to go to those places. Laurent Garnier, David Guetta â this might be surprising â but David Guetta used to DJ with Laurent Garnier in a famous club called Boy. I could never go because I was too young, but I know, people have given me this knowledge. So it was the first wave of electronic music in France and me, I discovered it with the second wave, in â92, in these big raves in warehouses outside Paris. At the time I was skateboarding, all my life was about heavy metal and crazy stuff. But we were there, ten guys, we arrived in this warehouse, 3.000 or more. Lenny D, Ralphie Dee, all those names you know from this â90s electronic scene.

Gerd Janson

They were playing hard and fast techno.

Pedro Winter

Itâs good youâre jumping on this because it was really hard music at the time. I enjoyed this rave thing and this crazy experience for a few years. Then at some point three years later, I was a bit fed up. Going to those raves was kind of a trip a trip, you had to take these shuttle buses outside Paris, not that easy. Youâre like one or two hours away from Paris at seven in the morning. What the fuck am I doing here? So I gave up on it and discovered that Paris had some nice clubs. One of them was Rex club, where a famous DJ called Laurent Garnier was throwing parties called Wake Up. Wow! Derrick May, Juan Atkins, all those guys were spinning with Laurent Garnier and it was 20 minutes away from home. No more mud on my shoes, no more crazy trips. Then I discovered this techno music. Before that, in the raves, especially early â90s, it was trance-y. Today, I donât think I would listen to it. Then I discovered techno music, then from club to club you discover other music and I discovered house music. We have the French radio, which is unfortunately now a bit crap, called Radio FG. It was a gay or alternative radio that turned into more of an electronic and house radio [station]. DJ Deep, who was a very famous DJ in Paris, and DJ Gregory had a show. It was called Deep Groove, and it was all about house music. I spent my money buying records, but then I wanted to be more a part of this electronic thing. You are part of it, Iâd like to say that, this whole movement. You are part of it from the dancefloor, people in the clubs. Itâs not all about the DJs, the VJs, the promoters. Itâs about people who are dancing. From dancing I thought, âI wanna be that guy,â so I wanted to become a DJ. In â95 I started to DJ, again in this whole electronic movement thing. Then I thought, âI want to play my own record,â so I produced myself. Then I thought, âI want to have my own label,â on and on and on, being part of it, feeling responsible for what we are doing, now with Ed Banger, but also with Daft Punk and other artists. I threw my whole body into this electronic movement.

Gerd Janson

Do you have any of these house tracks with you? Something that grabbed you back then and never left you.

Pedro Winter

I should have prepared this one.

Gerd Janson

You said you like it to be unprepared.

Pedro Winter

You know what? We are lucky. Itâs kind of symbolic, even though itâs not completely pure New York house music. But itâs someone I really like, and I just found him. Itâs nothing to do with house from New York City, itâs an artist called Daniel Wang from Balihu Records, youâve probably heard of him.

(music: Daniel Wang â unknown)

Gerd Janson

This track is also an example of using samples in a nice way, right? Itâs full of them.

Pedro Winter

Itâs full of them. But since when is using samples a problem?

Gerd Janson

It became one for Danny Wang himself. He started saying itâs very bad using samples and he hates his old stuff and no one should sample and everyone should just do their own music.

Pedro Winter

Sometimes people change their mind, you know. But he was good using samples and heâs still good without. But, of course, if we want to go on this debate, using samples and not using samples. Of course, itâs a waste of time. Use samples as much as you want. If you sample my artists, we will sue you. [laughter] Thatâs all I can tell you.

Gerd Janson

Have you ever got into problems using samples?

Pedro Winter

Iâve never got into problems, but to be clear, it takes time and costs money. Right now, on Ed Banger we have an artist called Uffie, a female MC. Weâre going to release her album at the end of May this year. Iâm still working on the paperwork to clear some of the samples because some of my artists, like Mr. Oizo still think they can sample and give me some tracks. âOh Pedro, release it.â Man, you sampled.

Gerd Janson

So they donât tell you what they used?

Pedro Winter

Sometimes they donât tell me, now they understand they have to tell me. But itâs part of the game. Me, you have to be fair, if youâre sampling someone, you have to share. Iâve never had any trouble, but if you want I will tell you this little funny thing. Iâm sure we all share the same love for this Detroit artist called Jay Dee, and I think was about eight or nine years ago for his band Slum Village, he sampled a track by one of the Daft Punk boys. Because we knew Jay Dee and listened to the Slum Village album, we were, âWow! He did something pretty good with that.â Of course, at the time Daft Punk, we were surrounded by Virgin Records and their lawyers, and they were all, âPedro, you canât let it go, you have to say something.â âYeah, of course, Iâm going to say something, but Iâm not going to go on Jay Deeâs back.â So we took our phone and called Jay Deeâs manager at the time and I think we did something pretty cool, we asked him to return the favor. So he did a remix for Daft Punk and he did a brilliant track and now, with the history, Iâm pretty glad we did it this way. I donât know if you know this one.

(music: Daft Punk â âAerodynamic (Slum Village Remix)â)

So yeah, sometimes sample issues make good things. Itâs not all about a shitty contract.

Gerd Janson

They can be cleared in another way.

Pedro Winter

Exactly.

Gerd Janson

Now weâve got back to Daft Punk, please fill us in on the magic fairy tale. So you met those two guys and they said, âHey, you want to become a lawyer?â

Pedro Winter

Letâs do it quick, you know, because there is not much to say about it. Twenty-years old, I didnât know nothing about the music business. The boys, too, didnât know nothing about the music business. They were also 20 years old. I started work for them in summer â96 and in September we took the Eurostar for the first time in our lives, and we were invited to Virgin Records. You can imagine, 20 years old, wow! Weâre like this, looking all around. The boys signed the contract with Virgin. The album came out January 1997, it was Homework. After that it all happened, I hope you all know of Daft Punk.

Gerd Janson

Is someone not familiar with Daft Punk?

Pedro Winter

First, the most important thing I owe them is them being genius. So from that day, they have to have the full credit of their success. Their intelligence they had at the time, and it wasnât easy for some kids. I really insist on the fact that we were 20 years old and at the time itâs really hard. You are young and success is coming near you, itâs really hard to say no. I think the secret of Daft Punk is being king of the no. I was the king of the no, because I was the one saying no to everybody. They protect themselves and we get everybody from BjÃ¶rk to Madonna to George Michael knocking on the door.

Gerd Janson

What do you do when Madonna calls?

Pedro Winter

You hang up the phone â not with her, but her manager â and call the boys and say, âWoah, woah, woah, weâve got Madonna on!â But at the same time, this is the funny thing. They were not running after success or fame, and they knew what they didnât want to do.

Gerd Janson

Pictures, for instance.

Pedro Winter

What is that?

Gerd Janson

Photographs.

Pedro Winter

Oh, yes. They wanted to protect themselves, hiding. They want to be cool, to take the subway in Paris, go to the bakery without being assaulted. So they knew what they didnât want to do, and they knew what they wanted to do. They managed a career with a dream of being an artist and being able to express yourself with music, your movies and your videos. All the money they got, they reinvested it in their productions. When we did the videos with Michel Gondry, with Spike Jonze, those names youâve probably heard of, at the time it was a lot of money. Even though nowadays unfortunately no one cares about video. At the time we were spending a lot of money. We were creating art. We were creating pieces. Now, no one cares.

Gerd Janson

Why is that?

Pedro Winter

I donât know, I donât have the answer.

Gerd Janson

MP3 killed the video star?

Pedro Winter

No, no, no, MP3 saved lazy DJs like us. Me, I will not go into this talk about how it was better back in the day. When we used to take time, spend money, it was a different time. Iâm more talking about difference rather than better. Iâm very happy and Iâm sure you guys are happy to live in 2010. Look at our equipment, Iâve seen the studio upstairs, you can make an album in a week, release it the next day, sell it on iTunes, Beatport or whatever, send it to your friend in Tokyo. Iâm happy to live in 2010.

Gerd Janson

Me, too, but I meant, why do you think video is not important anymore?

Pedro Winter

Because there are no more channels. There is no more TV.

Gerd Janson

There is a channel called YouTube.

Pedro Winter

Yeah, come on, do you get money out of YouTube? They donât share their success with the label, with the artists. YouTube screen your movies, your art, you get nothing out of it, and theyâre selling adverts â before I watch your video I have to see some crazy advert for whatever. But anyway, thatâs not the point. Iâm more talking about the change. Itâs good to live with your time. Evolution is a good thing. I will not go too deep into this. There are still some artists doing funny videos, cheap videos. But going back to Daft Punk, they were reinvesting all their money, got the success they deserved, and another good thing, they were rare. They didnât run after fame or success, so they took their time. Again, as we are in an academy, we have to pass the knowledge to each other. Me, as an adult now â wow, fuck! â I keep telling my artists on Ed Banger to take their time. We are not in a rush and time is good to avoid mistakes and, most important, to get better. Daft Punk have only released three albums in, like, 15 years. So itâs kind of a slow production process, but at the same time theyâve achieved at the same time doing videos, photos. I donât know if any of you were at their live shows in 2007, with the old pyramid and all-light shows. This was a pretty crazy thing to put up together. And again, they hit touchdown with this.

Gerd Janson

Was there a certain moment from meeting those two guys in a record shop to when you realized there was something going on? Was it listening to one of their tracks in a club or was it just the Eurostar to London?

Pedro Winter

First, an important thing. I was a fan, even though they just did two 12"s before I knew them. But âNew Waveâ and âDa Funkâ were two tracks by Daft Punk I was blown away when I listened to it, so when I met them, of course I had something to tell them. It was in â95, again it was kind of a 109 BPM, George Clinton-getting-grunge kind of track. No one knew what it was. Do you want me to play it?

Gerd Janson

Yes, if people want to hear it.

Pedro Winter

For those who donât know.

(music: Daft Punk â âDa Funkâ)

You know what? Iâm sharing something with you. This is a track that nowadays when Iâm DJing people are singing it, they sing it, you know they are. âLaa, la-la-la-la.â Itâs always impressed me.

Gerd Janson

I was singing it yesterday, all day.

Pedro Winter

Under the shower? We can speak on Daft Punk. So yeah, I was a fan, and then having the chanceâ¦ I had a really nice Chinese meal with Thomas of Daft Punk in summer of â96 and he said, âWe are in the studio right now, you should come and check it out. And weâre going to need someone, a right-hand man or something.â It wasnât really a manager at the time because neither of them knew what a manager was. He was like, yeah, do you want to join us? I think it took me 40 seconds to say yeah, letâs try, letâs give up everything. I quit the nightclubs in Paris because at the time I was doing parties. So I gave up on all those parties and started sending my faxes from Thomasâ studio because at the time we didnât have an office. It was all faxes, no emails, the email stories would come soon. Send faxes to people saying, âYeah, Daft Punk can come to here to Germany and play,â receiving contracts by fax. Really boring.

Gerd Janson

But how did you work your way through it, not knowing anything about the dangerous music business?

Pedro Winter

Again, I think this is the thing, being completely naÃ¯ve and fresh and new. Itâs like, we give you guys a new sampler or computer or keyboard, some new stuff, you try it and you have an accident, and when you make accidents you make magic.

Gerd Janson

But, for instance, these guys in Chicago back in the day who were probably influential to Daft Punk, they were naÃ¯ve and innocent as well and they signed all their rights away.

Pedro Winter

True, true, but we can go deeper into this. Thomas of Daft Punk has a father called Daniel Vangarde, who is an old disco hitmaker in France. You probably know some of his tracks, like Ottawan, âD.I.S.C.O.â Hey, come on Patrick, he knows it. So luckily, Thomasâ father got some music business knowledge and it helped a lot at the beginning, so to avoid signing crazy contracts or making bad mistakes at the beginning. But after that, signing with Virgin, and especially a man called Emmanuel de Buretel, who used to run Virgin France, who believed in Daft Punk and had some different approach to the business. As I said earlier, Daft Punk wanted to change the game, so they proposed some different ideas, they proposed a different contract and on and on. We tried to make things move, and even though we were that small [makes a tiny zero with his hand] in the game, we were the little sand thing that makes things move. Then there was the fact we were lucky, arriving at the moment when electronic music crossed the border. I donât want to go too much on a sad thing, like back in the days techno was a forbidden music or whatever. Of course, it was there before that. But still in â96, â97, electronic music wasnât as big on the radio or the TV shows. We were still close to the early years when electronic music was still the devilâs music, or gay music. It was something that was not accepted. Now, youâre opening the Olympics with David Guetta. So Daft Punk, Chemical Brothers, Prodigy, all those bands in the mid â90s pushed the boundaries further and made it more pop music.

Gerd Janson

So what do you think was pop about Daft Punk? That you can sing it along without lyrics?

Pedro Winter

Exactly. And also it was a question of time. Like, I donât think Daft Punk is more melodic than Derrick May, or stuff like that. It was just a question of time. Weâll speak about it later with Ed Banger, what I have been doing for the last years with Ed Banger. You are at the crossing of time where you are the right punk. Luckily, Daft Punk, with the help of Virgin Records at the time â we have to be true, having such a record company behind you helps to break boundaries. Itâs not something we did alone.

Gerd Janson

I know Iâm kind of obsessed with pictures, but what did they say about the method of not having pictures?

Pedro Winter

Oh, good question. You can imagine, a record company having an artist who says, âI donât want to do any promotion, I donât want to do interviews, I donât want to do pictures,â the guys at the record company want to kill themselves. âIâm spending millions, I want you to be number one, you want to hide?â But after a few meetings and fights they understood that point of view, they respected that. Thatâs why we have to be cool to Virgin, they were smart enough to trust the band, who had a vision. But this idea of hiding themselves wasnât like a marketing thing or whatever, they just didnât feel it. It was naÃ¯ve and fair to themselves.

Gerd Janson

Itâs nice that you have them in your robot persona toys.

Pedro Winter

Yeah, I have toys of them. I quit Daft Punk management a couple of years ago now.

Gerd Janson

Speaking of timeâ¦

Pedro Winter

I spent 12 years with them, and I like to think that when we split, it was more like youâre 18 years old and your parents are looking at you and saying, âItâs time to have your own place now.â I felt a bit like that with Daft Punk. It was about time, and I wanted to try some other things.

Gerd Janson

And are you still in touch with your parents?

Pedro Winter

Iâm still visiting my parents, those bastards are living in Los Angeles now. So, Los Angeles. Big houses, big cars.

Gerd Janson

Theyâre living the dream.

Pedro Winter

Weâre far away from the good old days when they were punkâ¦ If youâre watching, Daft Punk. No, now theyâre enjoying life and they deserve it more than anything. And most important, Iâm still a big fan and Iâm looking forward to listen to what they are doing for Tron, theyâre doing the soundtrack for Tron. Disney is spending billions of dollars and they are smart to have the idea to call Daft Punk to do the soundtrack. So Iâm looking forward to it. I closed down the big Daft Punk chateau with a big au revoir to Daft Punk.

Gerd Janson

What did you when you left your parentsâ house?

Pedro Winter

When I left my parents I had an idea of setting up â because as you can imagine, spending time with Daft Punk is like living with a giant magnet, I keep receiving music or artists saying, âOh, I want you to be my manager.â But it was too much.

Gerd Janson

It was like Facebook before Facebook.

Pedro Winter

Wow, good one! It was Facebook. Everybody wanted to become my friend, and at the time we didnât have the auto-accept thing. [laughter] But out of those guys who tried to contact me I met a guy called Mr. Flash, a hip-hop producer from France. He sent me some tracks and he said, âPedro, I want you to be my manager.â And I was, âNo more, no more, I want to do something else.â Then one day, it was a Thursday, and that morning I didnât know I would set up a label, I said, âOh, Iâm going to put out your music.â And I put out a track called âRadar Rider,â which was a pure instrumental hip-hop track, really in the DJ Shadow â to give him his respect â big opera, instrumental hip-hop. So I put it out as the first Ed Banger. And my friend Philippe Zdar of Motorbass gave me a B-side, so I put out this first Ed Banger without knowing what I was doing. It was 2003, all the French labels were closing down, every record company was spending millions trying to find the new Daft Punk, all the UK was still dreaming of disco filter house and I wanted something new, something different. During a famous cheese party â I was invited to a cheese party â I met two young kids.

Gerd Janson

To a cheese party?

Pedro Winter

Yes, Iâm French. I respect you guys from Norway or whatever, so respect my Frenchy style. [laughter] We fucking eat cheese like pork. And itâs melted cheese, itâs hot, fondue. Raclette. So we were on a big table, I was surrounded by younger kids. Two of them, one little Chinese, one with curly hair, at the end of the meal went, âPedro, weâve been making some music. Can you come in the room?â And we went into Gasparâs room and they played me âNever Be Alone (We Are Your Friends).â It was 2003, and I told them to come to my office the next day. Three days later I was playing in a French club that is closed now, called Pulp.

Gerd Janson

Pulp is where people like ChloÃ© and Ivan Smagghe.

Pedro Winter

Kill the DJ, Ivan Smagghe, it was a lesbian club at the beginning. Again, weâre going back to the gay scene. It was a really nice club, a small thing, 300 people. I was playing one night there and I played that track and something happened. Some guys came up to me, âWhatâs that track?â By the time I do the artwork with Sony and press the vinyl, we put out this record, and I lived on this record for three years, I think. This smiling is not really what Iâm expecting. When I say I lived on it, I didnât live on the money, because you donât make any money out of it. Even though you sell five thousand vinyls, you donât make that much money out of it. But it gave us enough energy, it gave Justice the confidence to become a real band, give up their jobs, go in the studio and record their first album. You know in a computer game, when you have a racing car, you have the speed thing, how do you call it? [inaudible from participant, speaks French] But which one do you have here? Nitro, better! Sorry, I got to nitro. So letâs say âWe Are Your Friendsâ was the nitro of Ed Banger. So you can imagine, I felt pretty lucky. Second release of a label. Even though my story being Daft Punk manager, doing a new label wasnât that easy. This is where life is pretty funny.

Gerd Janson

But you havenât had Daft Punk on the label.

Pedro Winter

I havenât had Daft Punk, but inside I was, âAll those guys who used to call me, who used to be my best friends, maybe they will play my stuff on the radio,â and itâll be [mimes taking phone call], âHello? Hello?â I take it as fun because itâs pretty fair, it canât happen like this [clicks fingers]. But finally, it happened like this with Justice.

Gerd Janson

Do you have it with you? Maybe one or two peopleâ¦

Pedro Winter

I donât have it, I donât play this kind of shit in my... [laughter]

Gerd Janson

In your spare time?

Pedro Winter

Because we are here talking between friends and no one is hearing us or seeing usâ¦

Gerd Janson

Eh, a few people might.

Pedro Winter

I really think with âWe Are Your Friendsâ we were lucky enough to release a track thatâs important for a generation. And I think âWe Are Your Friendsâ will be important for what happened for Ed Banger and for the club scene. A track becoming one of the biggest for house DJs, and [some who] used to be a big hip-hop head, all those.

Gerd Janson

So like Daft Punk it crossed over.

Pedro Winter

Yes. Completely. Completely crossed over. Mixing things and reuniting worlds. Talking about Ed Bangerâs parties, or Foolâs Gold, Mad Decent or Stones Throw, when we throw those parties we have hip-hop heads wearing crazy colored sneakers. We have indie kids ready to rave. All these mixed things and I like being part of it.

Gerd Janson

Whatâs your theory for having all these hip-hop backpackers going crazy to these tracks, when normally theyâre too cool for school?

Pedro Winter
